macOS.summary: Install using npm and configure servers via MCP settings file
steps: Install Node.js 18+ if not already installed: brew install node
Clone the repository: git clone https://github.com/modelcontextprotocol/servers.git
Navigate to specific server directory: cd servers/src/[server-name]
Install dependencies: npm install
Build the server: npm run build
Configure in your Claude desktop config at ~/Library/Application\ Support/Claude/claude_desktop_config.json
macOS.notes: Each server has its own dependencies and configuration. Check individual server READMEs for specific requirements. Some servers require API keys.

linux.summary: Install using npm and configure servers via MCP settings file
steps: Install Node.js 18+: curl -fsSL https://deb.nodesource.com/setup_18.x | sudo -E bash - && sudo apt-get install -y nodejs
Clone the repository: git clone https://github.com/modelcontextprotocol/servers.git
Navigate to specific server directory: cd servers/src/[server-name]
Install dependencies: npm install
Build the server: npm run build
Configure in your MCP client's config file
linux.notes: Requires Node.js 18 or higher. Some servers may require additional system dependencies.

windows.summary: Install using npm via Node.js for Windows
steps: Download and install Node.js 18+ from https://nodejs.org/
Clone the repository: git clone https://github.com/modelcontextprotocol/servers.git
Navigate to specific server directory: cd servers\src\[server-name]
Install dependencies: npm install
Build the server: npm run build
Configure in your MCP client's config file
windows.notes: Use PowerShell or Command Prompt. Some servers may have platform-specific limitations.

docker.summary: Not the recommended approach for MCP servers
docker.notes: MCP servers are designed to run as local processes that communicate with LLM applications. Docker containerization adds unnecessary complexity for this use case.
docker.rationale: MCP servers need direct filesystem and process access to integrate with local applications. Running in Docker would require complex volume mounting and networking configuration.

macOS.summary: Clone and run individual quickstart projects
steps: Ensure Python 3.10+ or Node.js 18+ installed (depending on quickstart)
Clone the repository: git clone https://github.com/anthropics/anthropic-quickstarts.git
Navigate to desired quickstart: cd anthropic-quickstarts/[quickstart-name]
Follow the README in each quickstart directory for specific setup
Set ANTHROPIC_API_KEY environment variable: export ANTHROPIC_API_KEY='your-key-here'
Install dependencies and run as per quickstart instructions
macOS.notes: Each quickstart is self-contained. Some require additional API keys or services. Check individual READMEs for specific requirements.

linux.summary: Clone and run individual quickstart projects
steps: Ensure Python 3.10+ or Node.js 18+ installed
Clone the repository: git clone https://github.com/anthropics/anthropic-quickstarts.git
Navigate to desired quickstart: cd anthropic-quickstarts/[quickstart-name]
Follow the README in each quickstart directory
Set ANTHROPIC_API_KEY: export ANTHROPIC_API_KEY='your-key-here'
Install dependencies and run as per quickstart instructions

windows.summary: Clone and run individual quickstart projects via PowerShell or WSL
steps: Install Python 3.10+ or Node.js 18+ from official websites
Clone the repository: git clone https://github.com/anthropics/anthropic-quickstarts.git
Navigate to desired quickstart: cd anthropic-quickstarts\[quickstart-name]
Follow the README in each quickstart directory
Set ANTHROPIC_API_KEY: $env:ANTHROPIC_API_KEY='your-key-here'
Install dependencies and run as per quickstart instructions
windows.notes: WSL2 recommended for better compatibility with some quickstarts. Computer use demo requires additional setup on Windows.

steps: Clone the repository: git clone https://github.com/anthropics/anthropic-quickstarts.git
Navigate to quickstart with Docker support
Check for docker-compose.yml or Dockerfile
Set ANTHROPIC_API_KEY in .env file
Run: docker-compose up
docker.notes: Not all quickstarts support Docker. Computer use demos may have limited functionality in containers.
docker.rationale: Most quickstarts are simple enough to run locally. Docker adds overhead without significant benefits for these educational examples.

macOS.summary: Create new SvelteKit project using npm create
steps: Ensure Node.js 18+ is installed: node --version
Create new project: npm create svelte@latest my-app
Follow the prompts to configure your project
Navigate to project: cd my-app
Install dependencies: npm install
Start dev server: npm run dev
macOS.notes: SvelteKit requires Node.js 18.0 or higher. Use npm create svelte for latest templates.

linux.summary: Create new SvelteKit project using npm create
steps: Install Node.js 18+: curl -fsSL https://deb.nodesource.com/setup_18.x | sudo -E bash - && sudo apt-get install -y nodejs
Create new project: npm create svelte@latest my-app
Follow configuration prompts
Navigate to project: cd my-app
Install dependencies: npm install
Start dev server: npm run dev

windows.summary: Create new SvelteKit project using npm
steps: Download and install Node.js 18+ from https://nodejs.org/
Open PowerShell or Command Prompt
Create new project: npm create svelte@latest my-app
Follow configuration prompts
Navigate to project: cd my-app
Install dependencies: npm install
Start dev server: npm run dev
Create Dockerfile with Node.js 18+ base image
Mount project directory as volume
Expose port 5173 for dev server
Run: docker run -v $(pwd):/app -p 5173:5173 -it node:18 /bin/bash
Inside container: npm create svelte@latest . && npm install && npm run dev -- --host
docker.notes: Docker is useful for isolated development environments but adds complexity. HMR performance may be slower with volume mounts.
docker.rationale: SvelteKit's Vite dev server with HMR works best with direct filesystem access. Docker volume mounting can slow down hot reloading significantly.

macOS.summary: Install via npm and create new Hono project
steps: Create new project directory: mkdir my-hono-app && cd my-hono-app
Initialize npm project: npm init -y
Install Hono: npm install hono
Create index.ts with basic Hono app
For Cloudflare Workers: npm install -D wrangler
Run locally: npx wrangler dev index.ts
macOS.notes: Hono can run on multiple runtimes. Choose adapter based on deployment target (Cloudflare Workers, Deno, Bun, Node.js).

linux.summary: Install via npm and create new Hono project
steps: Create new project directory: mkdir my-hono-app && cd my-hono-app
Initialize npm project: npm init -y
Install Hono: npm install hono
Create index.ts with basic Hono app
Install runtime-specific dependencies if needed
Run with your chosen runtime (Node.js, Bun, Deno)

windows.summary: Install via npm and create new Hono project
steps: Create new project directory: mkdir my-hono-app && cd my-hono-app
Initialize npm project: npm init -y
Install Hono: npm install hono
Create index.ts with basic Hono app
For Cloudflare Workers: npm install -D wrangler
Run locally: npx wrangler dev index.ts

docker.summary: Run Hono app in Docker container
steps: Create Dockerfile with Node.js or Bun base image
COPY package files and install dependencies
COPY application code
EXPOSE appropriate port (usually 3000)
CMD to start your Hono server
Build: docker build -t my-hono-app .
Run: docker run -p 3000:3000 my-hono-app
docker.notes: Docker works well for Hono apps. However, for Cloudflare Workers deployment, use wrangler dev locally.
docker.rationale: While Docker works fine for containerized deployment, Hono shines on edge runtimes like Cloudflare Workers where Docker isn't applicable. Local development with wrangler or native runtime is simpler.

macOS.summary: Build and run using Xcode or Swift Package Manager
steps: Clone the repository: git clone https://github.com/bipark/swift_llm_bridge.git
Open the project in Xcode: open swift_llm_bridge.xcodeproj
Select your target device (macOS or iOS simulator)
Configure API keys in the project settings if required
Build and run: Cmd+R
macOS.notes: Requires Xcode 15.0+ and macOS 13.0+. For iOS target, you need an Apple Developer account for device testing.

docker.summary: Not applicable for this iOS/macOS-specific project
docker.notes: Docker is not suitable for Swift iOS/macOS development due to platform-specific requirements.
docker.rationale: Swift projects targeting Apple platforms require native Xcode toolchain and cannot run in Docker containers. iOS development specifically requires macOS and Xcode.

mobile.summary: Connect iOS device via USB or use iOS Simulator
steps: Connect iPhone/iPad via USB cable
Trust the computer on your iOS device when prompted
In Xcode, select your device from the device dropdown
Ensure your Apple ID is configured in Xcode preferences
Build and run the project: Cmd+R
mobile.notes: Physical device testing requires free or paid Apple Developer account. Simulator testing is free but may not support all LLM features.
